questions.text: In the post-myocardial infarction period, 69 years-old-man was being observed for 5 days after the event, Patients engaging in sudden or excessive physical activity during this time are at higher risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Rupture of the left ventricle, a catastrophic complication of acute myocardial infarction, usually occurs about 4 to 7 days after an infarction, when repair is just beginning. The anterior wall of the heart is the most frequent site of rupture.
  • Arrhythmias accounting for almost 50% of deaths shortly after myocardial infarction. The risk for serious arrhythmias (e.g., ventricular fibrillation) is greatest in the first hour and declines thereafter.
  • Ventricular aneurysms may develop in the fibrotic scar within 3-6 months after myocardial infarct
  • Myocardial, or pump, failure and mural thrombosis are other complications that may develop as a result of permanent damage to the heart after infarct.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, page number 551, 552.

questions.text: Non-Palpable purpura is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Purpura are of 2 types: palpable and non-palpable


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine (21st edition) – Section 3, Chapter 115, page number 903.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital anomaly may cause reflux of pancreatic secretions into the common bile duct?
questions.solution:
• Choledochal cysts :- (option d)
    • These cystic dilatations of the biliary tree, typically extrahepatic, which may cause reflux of pancreatic secretions into the common bile duct. The majority develop in children under the age of 10, but they may also first present in adulthood
    • It characteristically presents with pain, jaundice and a mass
    • F>M
    • Choledochal cysts are not true cysts, but rather a focal fusiform or spherical dilation of the common bile duct, which may secondarily obstruct the other extrahepatic biliary ducts or even the duodenum. The pathogenesis is unknown.
    • Choledochal cysts may be associated with other congenital abnormalities of the biliary tract and other sites
  • Congenital diverticula have been reported in 0.0008%-9% of gallbladders. They consist of single or multiple outpouchings of the wall that may occur anywhere in the organ. (Option B)
  • In biliary atresia, a progressive fibroinflammatory disease affecting both the extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts, the gallbladder and extrahepatic ducts may be completely absent or may be represented by a fibrous cord without a lumen
  • When the cystic dilation of the biliary tree occurs along with congenital hepatic fibrosis, the term Caroli syndrome is applied. (Option c)

Reference:

Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 18, page number:859.

Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 21, page number. 847

choices.text: HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets)

questions.text: A 25 years old primigravida (eighth month) female came to the opd section with Chief complaints of polydipsia, severe vomiting, progressive fatigue and loss of consciousness on & off. She also has got yellowish discolouration of sclera. She gave birth to a normal girl. Liver biopsy of this patient was taken 3 weeks afterwards. Which diagnosis suits better according to the following microphotograph?
questions.solution:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy :

  • It presents with a spectrum of disease ranging from subclinical or modest hepatic dysfunction (evidenced by elevated serum aminotransferase levels) to hepatic failure, coma, and death.
  • It is a rare disease affecting approximately 1 in 16,000 pregnant women.
  • This disease in some cases may involve an inherited disorder of metabolism.
  • In a subset of patients, both mother and father carry a heterozygous deficiency in mitochondrial long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl coenzyme A (CoA) dehydrogenase.
  • The homozygous-deficient fetuses and placenta fare well during pregnancy but cause hepatic dysfunction in the mother, because long-chain 3-hydroxylacyl metabolites produced by the fetus, or placenta, enter the maternal circulation and cause hepatic toxicity. Thus, this may be a rare instance of the fetus causing metabolic disease in the mother.
  • Microscopy - The diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy rests on biopsy identification of characteristic diffuse microvesicular steatosis in hepatocytes.
  • In severe cases, there may be lobular disarray with hepatocyte dropout, reticulin collapse, and portal tract inflammation, making distinction from viral hepatitis difficult. Cholestasis may also be present.
  • It progresses within days to hepatic failure and death.
  • The primary treatment is termination of pregnancy. Affected women present in the latter half of pregnancy, usually in the third trimester.
  • Symptoms are directly attributable to incipient hepatic failure, including bleeding, nausea and vomiting, jaundice, and coma.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 18, page number:865.

choices.text: High-grade dysplastic nodules never show small areas of Hepatocellular carcinoma
Outcomes are better for the unusual fibrolamellar variant of Hepatocellular carcinoma
Klatskin tumors, which are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts
The second most common cause of Hepatocellular cancer-associated death

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution:
• HCC (also known as liver cell carcinoma, and previously termed hepatocarcinoma or hepatoma) is the sixth most common malignancy worldwide and the second most common cause of cancer-associated death. (Option D)
  • In chronic liver disease, the earliest morphologic alterations that appear to correlate with the presence of "at-risk" hepatocytes are called "large cell change" and "small cell change"
  • Large cell change refers to hepatocytes that are larger than normal and often have enlarged, multiple, pleomorphic nuclei, without an increase in nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.
  • In small cell change, the hepatocytes have a high nuclear-tocytoplasmic ratio and mild nuclear hyperchromasia and/or pleomorphism.
  • More ominous are nodular lesionsin cirrhotic liver referred to as dysplastic nodules, which are often associated with small cell change. Dysplastic nodules differ from adjacent cirrhotic nodules in size, color, and vascularization, show varying degrees of dysplasia, and have clonal aberrations associated with full-blown HCC. Small areas of HCC may sometimes be seen in high-grade dysplastic nodules ("nodule in nodule appearance") (option a)
  • Overall outcomes in HCC are poor due to underlying liver disease and the intrinsic resistance of HCC to conventional chemotherapy. The overall 5-year survival rate is 30% for tumor confined to the liver and only 5% to 10% for cases with extrahepatic spread. Outcomes are better for the unusual fibrolamellar variant, with up to 40% of patients surviving 10 years or longer. (Option b)
  • Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma usually occurs in the noncirrhotic liver and typically forms a firm gray-white mass. Extrahepatic biliary adenocarcinomas include perihilar tumor known as Klatskin tumors, which are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts. (Option c)

Reference:

Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 18, page number 869, 870, 871.

Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 20, page number. 806.

choices.text: Older adults with h/o asthma in churg strauss syndrome
p-ANCA positive in granulomatosis with polyangitis
Pulmonary infiltrates are present in WG and not in CSD disease

questions.text: From following pathologic features of vasculitis, which one is true?
questions.solution:
• Small vessel vasculitis ( Pulmonary- renal syndrome)
  • Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage + Glomerulonephritis

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 11, page number 509.

questions.text: Which of the following types of nasopharyngeal carcinomas have the LOWEST incidence of EBV positivity?
questions.solution:
• Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) {Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the nasopharynx} is closely related to EBV infection.
  • Bimodal peak : 15-25 years and 60-69 years
  • Types :
    1. Keratinizing SCC
    2. Non-keratinizing SCC
      1. Differented
      2. Undifferentiated
  • Keratinizing SCC is not as strongly associated with EBV infection.
  • Signs of EBV infection were identified in pri- mary tumors as well as distant metastasis.
  • Lymphoepithelioma is a histologic appearance of nonkeratinizing NPC cells intimately associated with lymphocytes in and around the tumor cells.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 4, page number. 171.

choices.text: Erythroid hyperplasia with binuclear to multinu- clear erythroblasts in the bone marrow
Failure of normal glycosylation of membrane proteins

questions.text: Characteristics of congenital dyserythropoietic anemia type II include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
There is excess binding of C3 to these cells which is thought to be related to decreased N-acetylglucosaminyl- transferase levels in CDA II.


Reference: Wintrobe's clinical hematology (21st edition) chapter 41.

questions.text: Which of the following RBC abnormalities is not seen with unstable haemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Unstable haemoglobins: Instability of haemoglobin molecule arises from mutations that interfere with structural relationship between globin chains and haem. Instability results in precipitation of haemoglobin with formation of Heinz bodies that attach to the red cell membrane. The red cells become rigid, and are sequestered and destroyed in the spleen.

  • Unstable haemoglobins are associated with increased anisocytosis and poikilocytosis on the peripheral smear. (Option c)
  • The heinz body test is usually positive. (Option A)
  • Because a hemolytic anemia is often involved, polychromatic cells (Reticulocytosis) is usually present. (Option B)
  • Other tests to identify unstable haemoglobin:
    • Isopropranolol stability test
    • The heat stability test.
      • /ul>

    Reference: Essentials of hematology, 2nd edition, section 2, chapter 2,4. page number, 69,130, 169, 191.

choices.text: The polyclonal Igs detected as abnormal protein "spikes" in urine electrophoresis and then further characterized by immunofixation
Hypocalcemia, renal failure, low level of hemoglobin, and osteolytic bony lesions can be present
Rouleaux formation and markedly raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) are typical features and result from hyperglobulinaemia
Lesions begin in the cortex of the bone, erode cancellous bone, and progressively destroy medullary cavity

questions.text: Following microscopic image of bone marrow aspiration smear of a 57 years old male having hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged lymph nodes. The bone lesions appear radiographically as punched-out defects, 2 CM in diameter. Choose the correct statement from the following on the basis of clinical, radiological and hematology details.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of above case is Multiple Myeloma.

  • Multiple myeloma (MM) is a neoplasm of terminally differentiated B lymphocytes called plasma cells characterised by
    1. Formation of multifocal tumour masses composed of plasma cells at multiple (bone marrow-based) locations in the skeleton,
    2. Suppression of normal immunoglobulin production (hypogammaglobulinaemia)
    3. Production of a monoclonal protein (paraprotein). This causes bone pain, osteolytic lesions, hypercalcaemia, and anaemia (Option A)
  • Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors (plasmacytomas) involving the axial skeleton.
  • The bones most commonly affected are:
  • Vertebral column > ribs > skull > pelvis > femur > clavicle > scapula.
  • Lesions begin in the medullary cavity, erode cancellous bone, and progressively destroy the bony cortex, often leading to pathologic fractures; these are most common in the vertebral column but may occur in any affected bone. (Option D).
  • Radiology findings - The bone lesions appear as punched-out defects and consist of soft, gelatinous, red tumor masses.
  • The clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma relies on identification of clonal plasma cells in the marrow and the presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions). (Option B).
  • Relatively normal appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.
  • Flame cells with fiery red cytoplasm, Mott cells with multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets (microscopic image), and cells containing a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.
  • The globular inclusions are referred to as Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).
  • Commonly, high levels of M protein in the blood cause red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation. (Option C)
  • A markedly increased (or rapid) erythrocyte sedimentation rate is a typical feature. It is due to increased immunoglobulins. (Option C)
  • Rarely, tumor cells flood the peripheral blood, giving rise to plasma cell leukemia.
  • Bence Jones proteins are excreted in the kidney and contribute to a form of renal disease called myeloma kidney.
  • Immunophenotype - CD56, CD138.
  • Mnemonic : Ms
    • Male predominance
    • Melanized individuals (black)
    • Monoclonal plasma cell (origin)
    • M protein (M paraprotien)
    • Malignant
    • Mars bones (osteolytic)

Reference:

Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) – Chapter 13, page number 608, 609.

Essentials of hematology, 2nd edition, section 3, chapter 9, page number, 313-333.

questions.text: Which of the following test may help in differentiating hemophilia A from von Willebrand disease (vWD) ?
questions.solution:
Bleeding time will be prolonged in vWD and is normal in hemophilia A.

PT is normal in both vWD and hemophilia A so it cannot differentiate.

Similarly APTT will be prolonged in both the conditions.

Factor VII level will also be low in both the conditions.


Reference:

Essentials of hematology, 2nd edition, section 4, chapter 13, page number, 392.

William's (8th edition) page number 1887, 2078.

questions.text: Which of the following matching option is correct?
questions.solution:
Reference:

William’s 8th edition page number. 586.

Essentials of clinical pathology, 1st edition, chapter 22, pagenumber, 205.

questions.text: Which viral infection is most likely to be responsible for a clinical picture of fever and pulmonary infiltration 4 weeks after an allogeneic stem cell transplant?
questions.solution:
CMV (cytomegalovirus)

  • It remains an important complication post allogenic-SCT. Its reactivation is common in the first 3 months after transplant.
  • CMV infection post-transplant can manifest as pneumonia, hepatitis, gastroenteritis, retinitis or encephalitis.
  • Risk factors:
    • Seronegative patients with seropositive stem cell donors (30% chances)
    • Acute and chronic GVHD and
    • The use of mismatched or unrelated donors.
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP)
  • It has become a rare opportunistic infection due to the use of prophylactic regimens.
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci is an atypical fungus causing severe pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, particularly among allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients.
  • Before the use of prophylaxis, 5-16% of patients who received allogeneic marrow transplants developed P. Jiroveci pneumonia (PCP) with a median onset at 9 weeks post-transplantation and a mortality rate of up to 76%.
  • Since the use of effective prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, less than 5% of HSCT recipients still develop PCP.

Reference:

Boeckh M, Ljungman P. How I treat cytomegalovirus in hematopoietic cell transplant recipients Blood. 2009, Thomas' Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation 4th edition,

Essentials of hematology, 2nd edition, chapter 12, page number, 377.

questions.text: Severe eosinophilia is defined as absolute eosinophil count more than:
questions.solution:
Blood eosinophil count above the upper reference limit (in adults more than 500/micl) is the hallmark of eosinophilia.

Mild Eosinophilia: blood AEC between 1500-5000/micl

Severe Eosinophilia: > 5000/micl.

The most common cause of eosinophilia is allergy and invasive parasite infections.

Reference: William’s, 8th edition, page number. 904.

choices.text: Decreased activity of an enzyme in the glycolytic pathway
Autoantibodies directed against the erythrocyte membrane
Clonal plasma cell dyscrasia with circulating paraprotien

questions.text: A 33 year old female presents with complaints of fatigue, fever, sore throat. On Palpation, generalized lymphadenopathy is present, largest at the cervical lymphnode level II. A CBC reveals atypical lymphocytes. The monospot test is positive. 3 weeks later, she complains of tingling of finger tips and intermittent pain. A CBC discloses a mild, macrocytic anemia. According to the peripheral smear image, which following statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis - Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

  • The peripheral smear of this patient shows clumping of rbcs caused by agglutinins (Autoantibodies). Cold agglutinins are mostly IgM, are directed against the I/I antigen system, and act optimally at 4°C.
  • Cold agglutinins may be idiopathic or develop secondary to an underlying condition, most frequently infections (Epstein-barr virus - monospot test) and mycoplasma or lymphoproliferative disorders.
  • Most autoimmune hemolytic anemias are mediated by IgG antibodies that exert their maximal effectat body temperature (warm agglutinins).

Reference: Essentials of hematology, 2nd edition, section 2, chapter 4, page number, 197, 198.

choices.text: 10% of breast carcinomas are multifocal in Location
5% percent of breast carcinomas occur centrally (within 1 cm of the areola)
Breast carcinoma is slightly more frequent in the Right breast than in the left
Approximately 50% of breast carcinomas occur in The upper outer quadrant

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the location of breast carcinomas?
questions.solution:
• The location of breast carcinoma is generally indicated by quadrant. Only 3% of breast carcinomas are multifocal in location. (Option A)
  • Breast carcinomas have been shown to be slightly more frequent in the left breast than the right (option C), with some studies quoting a 13% difference between the two breasts.
  • 17% of breast carcinomas are located within 1 cm of the areola (option B)
  • 50% of breast carcinomas are located in the upper outer quadrant (option D), a figure related to the high amount of breast tissue in that quadrant. In fact, the marked difference in breast cancer frequency by quadrant is a function of the amount of breast parenchyma per quadrant.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 28, page number 1039.

choices.text: Expression of p53 and her2/neu is low
This lesion frequently shows apocrine differentiation, signet ring morphology and nuclear pleomorphism
Absolute risk of Invasiveness from in situ lesion is more than 50%

questions.text: A 48 years old female is diagnosed with the lesion shown in the microscopic image. Which following statement is true regarding this lesion?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis - Invasive lobular carcinoma

  • A classical invasive lobular carcinoma complete with the single cell file pattern of growth but exhibits a marked degree of nuclear pleomorphism and abundant cytoplasm.
  • It frequently shows apocrine metaplasia and focal signet ring morphology. (Option B) Tubule formation is absent.
  • Expression of p53 and HER2/neu is very high. (Option A)
  • Lack of E-cadherin staining is in keeping with the lobular nature of the tumor. (Option C)
  • Absolute risk of Invasiveness from in situ lesion is more than ~25-30%. (Option D)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 23, page number 1045, 1056, 1057.

questions.text: Which of the following microscopic feature is seen in acute viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Acute viral hepatitis

  • Liver size :- normal/enlarged (due to inflammation), or shrunken in those cases that are associated with acute liver failure and massive liver necrosis
  • Microscopically:-
    • Portal and lobular inflammatory infiltrate comprised predominantly of lymphocytes and variably admixed with plasma cells and eosinophils.
    • Necrosis or apoptosis of hepatocytes often with pigmented macrophages
    • Necrosis of groups of hepatocytes (i.e., confluent necrosis) may be seen in severe cases and can progress to necrosis of the entire lobule (i.e., panlobular or panacinar necrosis) or connect vascular structures (i.e., bridging necrosis)
    • Liver failure can develop with massive hepatic necrosis.
    • Piece meal necrosis is seen in chronic active hepatitis.


Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 18, page number 837, 838.

questions.text: Following is an microphotograph of biopsy of liver of a patient having mutations of HFE; Identify the special stain and one morphological change from the following image.
questions.solution:
Hemochromatosis

  • Because there is no regulated iron excretion from the body, the total body content of iron is tightly regulated by intestinal absorption.
  • In hereditary hemochromatosis, regulation of intestinal absorption of dietary iron is abnormal, leading to net iron accumulation of 0.5 to 1 g/year. The disease typically manifests after 20 g of stored iron has accumulated.
  • Severe hemochromatosis (hereditary or secondary) is characterized by
    • Deposition of hemosiderin in the following organs Liver > pancreas > myocardium > pituitary gland > adrenal gland > thyroid > parathyroid glands > joints > skin
    • Cirrhosis
    • Pancreatic fibrosis
  • In the liver, iron becomes evident first as golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes that stain with Prussian blue (given image).

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 18, page number 848, 849.

choices.text: Small warty vegetations along the line of the closure
Small or medium sized on either or both sides of the valves

questions.text: Which of the following is true for the vegetations of libmann sacks endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Endocarditis of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Libman-Sacks Disease)

  • Small (1 to 4 mm), sterile vegetations in the setting of systemic lupus erythematosus are termed Libman-Sacks endocarditis.
  • The lesions develop as a consequence of immune complex deposition, with activation of complement and recruitment of Fc-receptor-bearing cells;
  • Histologically - valvulitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance.
  • The vegetations can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium. Persistent injury can eventually result in valvular scarring and leaflet fusion, analogous to that seen in RHD.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, page number 562, 565.

questions.text: Which of the following is an not an indication of the is cardiac transplant?
questions.solution:
Cardiac transplantation is performed for severe, intractable heart failure of diverse causes - most commonly DCM and IHD; over 3500 per year are performed worldwide.

Long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation - Allograft vasculopathy.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, page number 580

questions.text: Choose the correct cancer from the following which metastasize to the heart?
questions.solution:
• Metastatic tumors to the heart occur in roughly 5% of patients dying of cancer; the most frequent:-
    • Lung (Bronchial) carcinoma
    • Breast carcinomas,
    • Melanomas
    • Leukemias, and Lymphomas.
  • Metastases can reach the heart and pericardium:
    • Retrograde lymphatic extension from the mediastinum (mostly carcinomas)
    • By hematogenous seeding (many tumors)
    • Direct contiguous extension (of intrathoracic tumors)
    • Venous extension (tumors of the kidney or liver)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, page number 580.

choices.text: Disease of the lung or pulmonary vessels

questions.text: A 50 years old chronic smoker complains having an edema in her ankles and feet. He has a history of chronic obstructive lung disease. Further investigation reveals that he has cor pulmonale with right sided heart failure. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the right-sided heart failure?
questions.solution:
• The term cor pulmonale refers to right ventricular hypertrophy caused by pulmonary hypertension secondary to disorders of the lungs or pulmonary vessels.
  • Other causes of right ventricular hypertrophy and failure, such as
    • Valvular disease
    • Con- genital defects
    • Left-sided heart failure
  • Therefore, although in general, the most common cause of right-sided heart failure is left-sided heart failure (option C), cor pulmonale with right-sided heart failure is due to an intrinsic disease originating in the lungs. (Option D)
  • Constrictive pericarditis can clinically mimic right-sided heart failure but is entirely unrelated to cor pulmonale.(option B)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, page number 533, 556.

questions.text: Which of the following oral cavity infection shows multinucleated giant cells?
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

  • Oral herpes usually presents as gingivostomatitis in children, pharyngitis in adults, and chronic mucocutaneous infection in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Most orofacial herpetic infections are HSV-1, but oral HSV-2 (genital herpes) infections do occur.
  • In children, primary infections are most common between 2 and 4 years of age. It is asymptomatic but may present as acute herpetic gingivostomatitis, with abrupt onset of vesicles and ulcerations of the oral mucosa along with lymphadenopathy, fever, and anorexia.
  • In adults, acute herpes pharyngitis is common and may recur.
  • Herpes vesicles, small to large bullae filled with clear, serous fluid. They rapidly rupture to become painful, red-rimmed, shallow ulcerations.
  • Microscopy :
    • Intracellular and intercellular edema and acantholysis.
    • Eosinophilic intranuclear viral inclusions, or several cells may fuse to produce giant cells (multinucleate polykaryons). These can be demonstrated by the diagnostic Tzanck test.
  • Vesicles and shallow ulcers usually clear spontaneously within 3 to 4 weeks, but the virus treks along regional nerves and eventually becomes dormant (i.e., latent) within local ganglia (e.g., the trigeminal ganglion)

Reference:

Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 16, page number 733.

Weedon's Skin Pathology (5th edition) - Chapter 27, page number 765.

questions.text: Risk factors for the development of laryngeal carcinoma include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Risk factors of laryngeal carcinoma

  • Tobacco smoke
  • Alcohol
  • Nutritional factors,
  • Asbestos exposure,
  • Irradiation
  • HPV infection.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 16, page number 743.
